title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text: Something motivational

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text: Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
ggplot2



A grammar of graphics
Consistent syntax
Flexible
Customisable
ggplot2.tidyverse.org
exts.ggplot2.tidyverse.org/gallery

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Components of a ggplot


Data (data =)
Coordinate system (x and y)
Aesthetics (aes())
Geometries (geom_*)

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
ggplot2 components: Data


# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Call ggplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins
)

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
ggplot2 components: Coordinates


# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Call ggplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = body_mass_g)
)

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
ggplot2 components: Geom


# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Call ggplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = body_mass_g)
) + 
  geom_histogram()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
ggplot2 components: Aesthetics


# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Call ggplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = body_mass_g)
) + 
  geom_histogram(
    color = 'navy',
    fill = 'lightblue'
  )

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
ggplot2 A note on style



# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Call ggplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = body_mass_g)
) + 
  geom_histogram(
    color = 'navy',
    fill = 'lightblue'
  )



library() calls on top
Plenty of # Comments
Spacing x = body_mass_g
Indentation
data = and (aes()) on separate lines
Geoms on new lines
color and fill on new lines






ggplot(data=penguins,aes(x=body_mass_g))+geom_histogram(color='navy',fill='lightblue')

Does the same but harder to read and debug!

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Mini Exercise



 5 minutes

Practice with ggplot2!
Modify the code on the left to produce the figure on the right! 



# Load libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Call ggplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = body_mass_g)
) + 
  geom_histogram(
    color = 'navy',
    fill = 'lightblue'
  )














Hints

This is a density plot
Enter ?geom_density() at the console to open the R Documentation. Scroll down to the section on Aesthetics to read about other modifiable aesthetics.

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Two numeric
Scatterplot


# Plot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = flipper_length_mm, 
      y = bill_length_mm)
) + 
  geom_point()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
One numeric, One categorical


# Plot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = island, 
      y = body_mass_g)
) + 
  geom_boxplot()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Aesthetic mappings
Map variables to visual elements


Colour
Fill
Shape
Size
Line type

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
section: Map flipper length to x position and bill length to y position
text:
Map flipper length to x position and bill length to y position


# Scatterplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = flipper_length_mm, 
      y = bill_length_mm)
) + 
  geom_point()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Map flipper length to colour


# Scatterplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(
    x = flipper_length_mm, 
    y = bill_length_mm,
    color = flipper_length_mm)
) + 
  geom_point()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Map flipper length to size


# Scatterplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(
    x = flipper_length_mm, 
    y = bill_length_mm,
    size = flipper_length_mm)
) + 
  geom_point()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Map species to colour


# Scatterplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(
    x = flipper_length_mm, 
    y = bill_length_mm,
    color = species)
) + 
  geom_point()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
section: Map species to colour and shape
text:
Map species to colour and shape


# Scatterplot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(
    x = flipper_length_mm, 
    y = bill_length_mm,
    color = species,
    shape = species)
) + 
  geom_point()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Mini Exercise



 5 minutes

Practice with ggplot2!
Modify the code on the left to produce the figure on the right! 



# Plot
ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(x = island, 
      y = body_mass_g)
) + 
  geom_boxplot()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Data prep

library(dplyr)

penguins |> 
  group_by(year, species) |> 
  summarise(count = n()) 



# A tibble: 9 Ã— 3
# Groups:   year [3]
   year species   count
  <int> <fct>     <int>
1  2007 Adelie       50
2  2007 Chinstrap    26
3  2007 Gentoo       34
4  2008 Adelie       50
5  2008 Chinstrap    18
6  2008 Gentoo       46
7  2009 Adelie       52
8  2009 Chinstrap    24
9  2009 Gentoo       44

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Global mapping Vs local mapping


penguins |> 
  group_by(year, species) |> 
  summarise(count = n()) |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(x = year, 
        y = count,
        group = species,
        label = count,
        color = species)
  ) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line() + 
  geom_text(nudge_y = 2)

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales


p

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: x-axis


p + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    "Year",
    breaks = 2007:2009)












Try entering 2007:2009 at the console!

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: y-axis


p + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    "Year",
    breaks = 2007:2009)  + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    "Count",
    limits = c(0,75))

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: y-axis


p + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    "Year",
    breaks = 2007:2009)  + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    "Count",
    limits = c(0,75),
    breaks = seq(0, 75, 25))












Try entering seq(0, 75, 25) at the console!

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Axis scales
We chose scale_x_continuous() and scale_y_continuous() because these are the natural scales for year and count which are numeric variables.

There are many other axis scales available for plotting different types of variables.


scale_*_continuous()
scale_*discrete()
scale_*_binned()
scale_*_log10()
scale_*_date()
scale_*_datetime()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: Colour


p + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    "Year",
    breaks = 2007:2009)  + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    "Count",
    limits = c(0,75),
    breaks = seq(0, 75, 25)) + 
  scale_color_manual(
    NULL,
    values = c('red',
               'orange',
               'blue')
  )

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: Colour


p + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    "Year",
    breaks = 2007:2009)  + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    "Count",
    limits = c(0,75),
    breaks = seq(0, 75, 25)) + 
  scale_color_manual(
    NULL,
    values = c('red',
               'orange',
               'blue'),
    label = c(
      'Gentoo' = 'Fast Swimmer',
      'Adelie' = 'Ice Dweller',
      'Chinstrap' = 'Rock Climber')
    )

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: Colour


p + 
  scale_x_continuous(
    "Year",
    breaks = 2007:2009)  + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    "Count",
    limits = c(0,75),
    breaks = seq(0, 75, 25)) + 
  scale_color_brewer(
    type = "qual",
    palette = "set1")

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Scales: Colour

library(RColorBrewer)
display.brewer.all()

title: Visualising data with ggplot2
text:
Mini Exercise



 20 minutes

Practice with ggplot2!



GoalHints Seriously, help


Can you use ggplot2 and the penguins data to produce the figure on the right?




Start by identifying the x, y and fill aesthetics that will go in to aes().
This plot combines geom_jitter() and geom_boxplot()
Setting the alpha = argument makes the boxplots transparent
Use scale_fill_manual() to control the fill colors for the three different species





# Fill in the blanks!
ggplot(
  data = ,
  aes(x = ,
      y = ,
      fill = )) +
  geom_jitter(shape = ) +
  geom_boxplot(
    alpha = ) + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    " ",
    limits = c( ,  )) + 
  scale_x_discrete(NULL) + 
  scale_fill_manual(NULL,
    values = c(' ',' ',' '))






















Back

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text: Illustrations from the Openscapes blog Tidy Data for reproducibility, efficiency, and collaboration by Julia Lowndes and Allison Horstâ€

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text: Illustrations from the Openscapes blog Tidy Data for reproducibility, efficiency, and collaboration by Julia Lowndes and Allison Horstâ€

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
dplyr is a grammar of data manipulation, providing a consistent set of verbs that help you solve the most common data manipulation challenges


dplyr.tidyverse.org/

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
dplyr verbs



filter()
select()
rename()
mutate()
arrange()
slice()
case_when()
pivot_longer()



Rename a variable?
Sort by a given variable?
Keep rows that match a condition?
Keep or drop columns?

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
section: Keep rows that match a condition with filter()
text:
Keep rows that match a condition with filter()


# Load dplyr library
library(dplyr)

# Load cars dataset
data(cars)

# Filter rows
cars |> 
  filter(speed == 10)


  speed dist
1    10   18
2    10   26
3    10   34







# Filter rows
cars |> 
  filter(speed >= 10 & dist <= 20)


  speed dist
1    10   18
2    11   17
3    12   14
4    12   20
5    15   20

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
section: Keep rows by position with slice()
text:
Keep rows by position with slice()


# Slice rows 1 to 3
cars |> 
  slice(1:3)


  speed dist
1     4    2
2     4   10
3     7    4







# Slice last 3 rows
cars |> 
  slice_tail(n=3)


  speed dist
1    24   93
2    24  120
3    25   85








# Slice speediest 3 rows
cars |> 
  slice_max(speed, n=3)


  speed dist
1    25   85
2    24   70
3    24   92
4    24   93
5    24  120

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends

section: Create more complex variables with case_when()
text:
Create more complex variables with case_when()


# Create a new variable
cars |> 
  mutate(
    class = case_when(
      speed <= 4 ~ "slow", 
      speed <= 10 ~ "average", 
      .default = "fast"

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
The pipe operator |>

# Sort by speed
cars |> arrange(speed)




|> is called the pipe operator
It takes the object on the left and passes it to the first argument of the function on the right





# Equivalent to above code snippet
arrange(cars, speed)




We can use |> to chain multiple dplyr verbs
keyboard shortcut is Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + M

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text: Created by Arthur Welle

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
The old pipe operator %>%
If youâ€™ve been using R for a while you may be familiar with the %>% pipe operator shipped with the magrittr package.





# Exactly the same thing!
cars |> 
  mutate(time = dist / speed)  |> 
  arrange(-time)  |>  
  slice(1)



# Exactly the same thing!
cars %>% 
  mutate(time = dist / speed) %>%
  arrange(-time) %>% 
  slice(1)






For simple cases, |> and %>% behave the same
|> is simpler
|> is implemented in base R

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
A note on style



# Data prep
cars |> 
  mutate(time = dist / speed) |> 
  arrange(-time) |> 
  slice(1)



Neat and easy to read!
Each verb on a new line
|> at end of line
Indentation
Use of spacing




Avoid this!

# Data prep
cars|>mutate(time=dist-speed)|>arrange(-time)|>slice(1)

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
Factors in R
Earlier we used case_when() to create a categorical variable with three categories: fast, average, and slow.


# Create a new variable
cars |> 
  mutate(
    class = case_when(
      speed <= 4 ~ "slow", 
      speed <= 10 ~ "average", 
      .default = "fast"
    ))

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
Factors in R
Factors are useful for handling categorical variables.


Category names
Ordering categories
Mapping colors to categories (later!)



To create a factor you must start by creating a list of the valid levels:


# Vector of valid levels
classLevels <- c('slow', 
                 'average', 
                 'fast')

# Create factor variable
factor(c('fast', 'slow'), 
       levels = classLevels) 


[1] fast slow
Levels: slow average fast

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
text:
Factors in R
Letâ€™s put it all together!


# Create a new variable
cars |> 
  mutate(
    class = 
      factor(
        case_when(
          speed <= 4 ~ "slow", 
          speed <= 10 ~ "average", 
          .default = "fast"),
        levels = classLevels)) |> 
  group_by(class) |>  
  summarise(
    mean = mean(speed)
  ) 


# A tibble: 3 Ã— 2
  class    mean
  <fct>   <dbl>
1 slow     4   
2 average  8.71
3 fast    17.1 





Now the ordering is by speed class, not alphabetically!

title: Cleaning data with dplyr and friends
section: Moving from wide to long data
text:
Moving from wide to long data
Consider the following dataset:



Back

title: Orientation to RStudio
text:
Weâ€™re going to spend two days working on R code so letâ€™s take a moment to open up RStudio to orientate ourselves.




Here is a snapshot of the RStudio environment.




Thereâ€™s a lot going on!




Letâ€™s break it down.




This is an R script file (.R extension). Here you can write R code to clean, analyse, and visualise data




Notice that this file is saved with a proper file name analysis.R so we can open and close the file and come back to the code as needed.




This area has several tabs. The Environment tab plays a key role in managing and visualizing the objects that exist in the current R session.




Various types of objects can exist in your environment, for example vectors, dataframes and lists.




Currently we can see the cars dataset and the meanSpeed value stored in the environment.




Notice the Git tab is also in this area. Weâ€™ll use that later.




There are several important tabs in the bottom right-hand corner




The Files tab shows us all the file in our project. Spot analsis.R!




From here we can open files or navigate to different folders.




Other important tabs in this area includes the Plots tab, where are plots will appear, and the Packages tab that has a list of all the installed packages.




Here we have the console.




The console allows you to run R commands interactively. You can type a command directly into the console and press Enter to execute it and view the results straight away.




The console keeps track of previously executed commands. You can use the  up and  down arrow keys to scroll through past commands, making it easy to re-run commands or modify and execute them again.




Working in the console is convenient for quick, interactive commands, but it doesnâ€™t save a persistent record of your entered commands so important code should always be saved in a script.




Finally, note this icon in the top right-hand corner. This tells us we are working in an R Project named cars-study.

title: Orientation to RStudio
text:
R Projects

Use R projects to keep all your code organised in a single space



Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Orientation to RStudio
text:
Relative paths

If the first line of your R script is
setwd("C:\Users\jenny\path\that\only\I\have")
I will come into your office and SET YOUR COMPUTER ON FIRE ðŸ”¥.


â€”Jenny Bryan in Project-oriented workflow

A huge advantage of working in project environments is that we can use relative paths instead of absolute paths.






Tip



It is bad practice to include absolute paths like C:\Users\jenny\path\that\only\I\have in your code



getwd()

[1] "/Users/z3509778/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-UNSW/Data Vis Workshop/CourseSite/lectures"

title: Data cleaning
text:
Aims
In this exercise you will use dplyr and other tools to read-in and clean the self-assessed health data from the National Health Survey. The raw data is the .xlsx file downloaded from the ABS data. The final output will be a .csv file in tidy data format. Essentially, we will use code to goâ€¦







From this messy excel sheet


To this tidy dataframe!





















Tidy data



Remember, in a tidy dataset:

Each variable is a column; each column is a variable.
Each observation is a row; each row is an observation.
Each value is a cell; each cell is a single value.

If you examine the output above you will see this is true for the clean data: there are three columns, and each column is a variable: status, state, and percent. Each row is an observation, telling us the per cent for every state and status combination. Finally, each cell is a single valueâ€”there are no merged cells.
None of these rules of tidy datasets hold for the original .xlsx file!

R for Data Science (2nd Edition)

title: Overview
text:
Letâ€™s start with the goal in mind! Here it isâ€”a 100% stacked bar chart showing the breakdown of self-rated health status for 8 states and territories.

The simple chart format is enhanced using techniques covered in this workshop.

Ordering The states and territories on the y-axis are ordered from top to bottom by the proportion of respondents describing their health status as Very good or Excellent.
Colour The chart uses a familiar traffic-light colour scheme, to distinguish between Poor and Excellent self-assessed health.
Text hierarchy The main chart title is an informative title highlighting the key message. A descriptive subtitle explains in more detail what is plotted in the chart while the data source is provided in the footnote.
Annotation Text annotations indicate the percentage response for each category. Note that the colour for these labels has been carefully chosen to contrast against the background colour and the labels have been suppressed for the â€˜Poorâ€™ category, to avoid overflow.
Story telling As well as having an informative chart title, the keywords Excellent and Very Good are emphasised with bold font and appropriate colours to help connect the title to the data and reinforce the message.



The data for this plot come from the National Health Survey (NHS) 2022, a face-to-face interview survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and designed to collect information on health behaviours, conditions prevalence, and risk factors in Australia. You can read more about the survey on the ABS website here.
These data are openly available for download in .xlsx format from the ABS website and a copy is also included in the workshop repo in the file national-health-survey-2022-table-2.xlsx.

title: Overview
text:
The data for this plot come from the National Health Survey (NHS) 2022, a face-to-face interview survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and designed to collect information on health behaviours, conditions prevalence, and risk factors in Australia. You can read more about the survey on the ABS website here.
These data are openly available for download in .xlsx format from the ABS website and a copy is also included in the workshop repo in the file national-health-survey-2022-table-2.xlsx.

Welcome
Welcome to Reproducible Data Visualisation with R!

title: Version control with git and GitHub
text:
The challenge
As data analysts, we produce a lot of files

code
figures
tables
reports

Organising these files is an important, albeit often unglamorous, part of our job.

title: Version control with git and GitHub
text:
The Challenge
Managing versions What do you do with old code?
Ensuring reproducibility Can others reproduce your results? What about your future self?
Facilitating collaboration Can other team members easily contribute?

title: Version control with git and GitHub
text:
The old school solution ðŸ›µ
The old school solution combines many practical strategies:


Using file naming conventions to track different file versions

analysis-16jun2024.do
analysis-19jun2024-mh.do
analysis-final.do
analysis-final-final.do

Note changes directly in code comments or separate documentation
Use shared folders, google drive etc
Share code and code snippets over email, slack etc

title: Version control with git and GitHub
text:
The old school solution ðŸ›µ

This is ok(ish) for one person working on a small project. But if the project is large, involves many people or goes on for a long time this approach very quickly breaks down

title: Version control with git and GitHub
text:
The new school solution ðŸš€
The new school solution is to use dedicated version control software.
There are a few options out there but by far the most popular choice is the combination of git + GitHub

title: Version control with git and GitHub
text:
Via git-scm.com


Git is software for tracking different versions of code files you are working on locally.



Via logos-world.net


GitHub is a cloud-based platform for sharing and collaborating on projects managed with Git
